poem:
"Of Caged Trains and Lost Journeys"

Bristol bathed in merciless rain-blight,
Its veins of iron silenced by the swell.
In Privatisation's shroud, a bitter plight -
no one's sin, yet all's private hell.
Late-light trapped by the hushed network,
still echoes the rhythms of industrial ghost.
A nation's pulse stuttered, frenzied and irked -
Infrastructure's victim, humanity's host.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Broken-rail Britain: my journey to the heart of the nation’s privatisation nightmare | George Monbiot The weather was worse than forecast. By the time I reached Bristol, at 5pm, all trains to the south-west had been cancelled, because of rising flood waters. It was no one’s fault – just one of life’s vicissitudes. What happened next was a different matter. I believe I’m still suffering the effects of it: I think privatisation has made me". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
